awd_titl_txt: Factors Which Enhance Urban Resilience in the Context of Societal Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Cynthia Robin, of Northwestern University, along with colleagues from the US and Belize, will conduct research to study how a city can survive, and even thrive, during periods of political and environmental stress in society.  As over half of the world lives in cities today, there is perhaps no more pressing question than: how can people create cities that are long-lived and successful?  Archaeology is uniquely suited to answer questions about the longevity of cities, because archaeologists can excavate long periods and time and can thus examine the long-term history of human cities and assess why some cities succeed and other cities fail.  The social, political, economic, and environmental pressures that modern people and cities face are not new and archaeology provides a means to evaluate how people in the past successfully and unsuccessfully dealt with challenges in establishing and maintaining cities.  The data that archaeologists generate about why cities succeed or fail takes on renewed importance in today's world in which developing successful, long-lived cities is an imperative.  Dr. Robin and her colleagues will train US and Belizean graduate and undergraduate students in archaeology.  They will develop educational programs for the general public, as well as University students, to demonstrate how knowledge about the past is important for creating a better world today and foster interest in archaeology and the preservation of antiquities.

Dr. Robin and her research team will examine how cities can develop socio-political and economic systems that allow them to withstand periods of political turmoil and environmental stress.  The research will take place in northern Belize, Central America, a region that is peripheral to major power centers in PreColumbian Maya society.  On the periphery of and at the crossroads between major power centers of the ancient Maya, cities in northern Belize were able to develop political and economic relations and resource extraction that allowed them to survive and thrive during periods of drought and political crisis that led to the decline and collapse of cities in core areas of Maya society.  Research will focus on the city of Aventura that thrived while cities around it in core Maya areas collapsed.  The research team will survey and map the city of Aventura using state of the art laser and digital technologies.  They will conduct test excavations across the city to understand a broad swath of the city and completely excavate three building groups to gain more in depth knowledge.  Through the archaeological survey and excavation of Aventura's 2500 year history, Dr. Robin and her research team will analyze archaeological, botanical, soil science, and osteological evidence to determine how this city succeeded when others failed.

por.por_cntn:
Resilience, the ability to survive and thrive during challenging or changing times, is crucial for human societies.  As over half of the world currently lives in cities, understanding urban resilience is a pressing topic. Dr. Cynthia Robin of Northwestern University along with colleagues from the US and Belize drew upon archaeological research to study the social, political, economic, and environmental factors which enhance urban resilience.  Archaeology is a discipline particularly suited to address questions of resilience because archaeology can provide us with a long view on the successes and failures of cities.

Our research took place at the ancient Maya city of Aventura in northern Belize, a city with a five millennia history.  To assess resilience, we focused our archaeological study of Aventura on a period of political and environmental stress in Maya society often referred to as the Terminal Classic (or collapse; 800-1000 CE) and the preceding Late Classic (600-800 CE) and subsequent Postclassic periods (1000-1500 CE).  We conducted an in-depth archaeological study of urban households across Aventura.  Excavating and understanding households provided us with a window into the lives and livelihoods of the people who lived at Aventura and how they navigated changes in their society.

We identified four key factors that were important to household and community resilience at Aventura.  First, less hierarchical socio-political relations foster resilient communities. Socio-political relations at Aventura that foregrounded group over individual needs, along with reduced rigidity, facilitated adaption to change and greater social sustainability over the long term. Second, resilient communities are economically nimble. Aventura was located in an intermediary position between the Peten and Yucatan, regions of the Maya area.  Through time residents shifted their socio-economic ties between these regions particularly with increasing political strife in the Peten region.  Aventura’s households also developed local production that served as a buffer in times of stress.  Third, Maya ideologies that viewed people, animals, plants, ancestors, and land as entwined provide a grounding in the world for urban residents, that fostered conservation and resilience. And fourth, Aventura was and is a spiritually meaningful place for Maya people. Through the lens of Aventura’s urban households, a picture of urban Maya resilience emerges.

Our research was undertaken through community partnership and collaboration that facilitated the development of the project, its questions, and an approach to education.  Understanding household and community resilience is as relevant for local communities in Belize as it is in the US.  Showcasing our work in Belize we developed a community fair called Aventura Archaeology Day, a week-long teacher, tour guide, and community workshop series called Ancient World Week, and an elementary school-age summer camp experience.
